anns.prefix: Here, we reconstruct the origins of
anns.postfix: self-resistance by sequencing the entire Nav gene family in newts and related salamanders.

anns.prefix: We show that moderate

anns.prefix: Resistance to
anns.postfix: (TTX), a potent neurotoxin, has evolved convergently in several distantly related organisms, including pufferfish, snakes, and newts (reviewed by Soong and Venkatesh 2006; Toledo et al. 2016), and therefore offers an ideal system to investigate the molecular basis of adaptive evolution (Arbuckle et al. 2017).

anns.prefix: Resistance to tetrodotoxin (

anns.prefix: The genetic basis of
anns.postfix: resistance, which is well established in tetrodotoxic puffer fish (Jost et al. 2008) and in snakes that consume TTX-bearing prey (Geffeney et al. 2002; Feldman et al. 2012; McGlothlin et al. 2014, 2016), involves amino acid substitutions in the toxin’s target, voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav).

anns.prefix: Indeed, resistant substitutions are present in all eight of the Nav genes within the genomes of multiple species of
anns.postfix: pufferfish (from the family Tetraodontidae; Jost et al. 2008) and in six of the nine Nav genes in Thamnophis sirtalis snakes that consume TTX-bearing Taricha newts (McGlothlin et al. 2014; Perry et al. 2018).

anns.prefix: The three brain channels Nav1.1, Nav1.2, and Nav1.3 of snakes remain
anns.postfix: sensitive, but presumably are protected from TTX by the blood-brain barrier (McGlothlin et al. 2014).

anns.prefix: In snakes, the evolution of extreme
anns.postfix: resistance appears to follow a predictable, stepwise substitution pattern across TTX-exposed members of the Nav gene family, with substitutions in heart and peripheral nerve channels preceding those in the muscle channel gene, Nav1.4, which evolves resistance only in snakes locked in coevolutionary arms races with highly tetrodotoxic amphibian prey (Feldman et al. 2012; McGlothlin et al. 2016; Perry et al. 2018).

anns.prefix: Results Results Genomic Structure of Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels Genomic Structure of Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels Genomic Structure of Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels We used targeted sequence capture to characterize Nav sequences from the genomes of five salamander species (order Urodela), including three
anns.postfix: newts (family Salamandridae, subfamily Pleurodelinae, tribe Molgini), Notophthalmus viridescens, Taricha torosa, and Taricha granulosa (n = 3 diploid individuals of each species), and two salamanders that do not possess TTX, Cryptobranchus alleganiensis (Crypotobranchidae) and Plethodon cinereus (Plethodontidae, n = 2 each).

anns.prefix: Evolution of
anns.postfix: Resistance in Salamanders Evolution of TTX Resistance in Salamanders Evolution of TTX Resistance in Salamanders We characterized levels of TTX resistance in each Nav paralog as extreme, moderate, and TTX-sensitive based on previous site-directed mutagenesis experiments in which substitutions were introduced to TTX-sensitive Nav channels and cross-membrane Na+ current was measured in vitro in the presence and absence of TTX (table 3).

anns.postfix: based on previous site-directed mutagenesis experiments in which substitutions were introduced to TTX-sensitive Nav channels and cross-membrane Na+ current was measured in vitro in the presence and absence of TTX (table 3).

anns.prefix: Our results confirm that T. granulosa has six paralogs with extreme
anns.postfix: resistance (table 3 and fig. 3).

anns.prefix: We also show that substitutions with extreme
anns.postfix: resistance are present in all six Nav paralogs in two other species of highly toxic newt, T. torosa and N. viridescens, indicating that the common ancestor of these three species possessed extreme TTX resistance.

anns.postfix: fish and in snakes that consume tetrodotoxic amphibians (table 3).

anns.prefix: No salamander species outside the clade of highly toxic newts possessed a full complement of
anns.postfix: Nav paralogs, indicating that the evolution of full physiological resistance coincided with the origin of extreme toxicity.

anns.prefix: However, we found at least three paralogs with moderate or extreme
anns.postfix: resistance in all salamander species we examined, indicating that the evolution of TTX resistance in newts built upon more ancient changes that first appeared in their nonnewt relatives.

anns.postfix: Nav paralogs, indicating that the evolution of full physiological resistance coincided with the origin of extreme toxicity.

anns.prefix: However, we found at least three paralogs with moderate or extreme
anns.postfix: resistance in all salamander species we examined, indicating that the evolution of TTX resistance in newts built upon more ancient changes that first appeared in their nonnewt relatives.

anns.prefix: Within the toxic newt lineage, we identified putative positive selection acting on three known
anns.postfix: sites: 1240 and 1532 in DIII and DIV of muscle channel Nav1.4 and 1529 in DIV of brain channel Nav1.1 (table 4).

anns.prefix: In Nav1.4, sites 1240 and 1532 contain resistance-conferring substitutions exclusively within toxic newts and these substitutions have been associated with extreme
anns.postfix: resistance in Taricha muscle fibers (Hanifin and Gilly 2015).

anns.prefix: Although this substitution does not appear to affect Na+ selectivity or to be sufficient in preventing
anns.postfix: from binding (Jost et al. 2008), it may alter channel firing properties, as this A1529G substitution resulted in substantially higher Na+ currents relative to the wild-type when introduced into a mammalian Nav1.4 channel (Jost et al. 2008).

anns.prefix: The same alanine to glycine substitution has been observed in Nav channels of
anns.postfix: flatworms (Jeziorski et al. 1997) and pufferfish (Jost et al. 2008), which suggests that it may play a role in TTX resistance in these organisms.

anns.prefix: The same alanine to glycine substitution has been observed in Nav channels of
anns.postfix: -bearing flatworms (Jeziorski et al. 1997) and pufferfish (Jost et al. 2008), which suggests that it may play a role in TTX resistance in these organisms.

anns.postfix: newts have evolved resistance to their own toxicity through multiple parallel changes in their Nav genes and that, similar to snakes that consume TTX-containing prey (McGlothlin et al. 2016; Perry et al. 2018), some of the resistance in this taxon is ancient, first appearing in an early salamander.

anns.prefix: We show that moderate TTX

anns.prefix: Discussion Discussion Here, we show that TTX-bearing newts have evolved
anns.postfix: to their own toxicity through multiple parallel changes in their Nav genes and that, similar to snakes that consume TTX-containing prey (McGlothlin et al. 2016; Perry et al. 2018), some of the resistance in this taxon is ancient, first appearing in an early salamander.

anns.prefix: Discussion Discussion Here, we show that TTX-bearing newts have evolved resistance to their own
anns.postfix: through multiple parallel changes in their Nav genes and that, similar to snakes that consume TTX-containing prey (McGlothlin et al. 2016; Perry et al. 2018), some of the resistance in this taxon is ancient, first appearing in an early salamander.

anns.prefix: However, although substitutions conferring moderate TTX

anns.prefix: This molecular parallelism emphasizes the strong structural and functional constraints on this gene family, which appear to limit the evolution of TTX
anns.postfix: to a small number of predictable pathways, leading to convergent and parallel changes across multiple taxa (Feldman et al. 2012).

anns.prefix: Finally, the evolution of physiological

anns.prefix: Our results reveal that similar to their coevolutionary partners, Thamnophis garter snakes, Taricha newts evolved extreme TTX
anns.postfix: through a stepwise process that built upon ancient changes that were in place millions of years before the arms race began.

anns.prefix: However, the pattern of TTX
anns.postfix: evolution in newts also displays important differences from that of their predators.

anns.prefix: First, perhaps because of the constitutive presence of TTX, newts display extreme levels of
anns.postfix: even in channels that are expressed in the central nervous system, which are protected by the blood-brain barrier in species that encounter TTX in their diet.

anns.prefix: We also show that although positive selection appears to be a strong driving force of the evolution of TTX
anns.postfix: in newts, gene conversion may have sped up the process of adaptive evolution in some Nav paralogs, and constraints have limited the possible locations and types of resistant substitutions to a small subset of realized genetic changes.

In order to test for changes in selective regimes in the Nav genes between salamanders and highly toxic newts (
anns.postfix: and Taricha species), we fit the following models to our Nav alignments: 1) one-ratio models (allowing for a single ω ratio among all sites and all branches of the phylogeny), 2) branch models (allowing for separate ω ratios for the foreground [toxic newts] and background [other salamanders]), 3) branch-site neutral models (allowing ω to vary both between toxic newts and other salamanders and among sites, with two possible categories: 0 < ω < 1 and ω = 1), and 4) branch-site models (allowing ω to vary both between toxic newts and other salamanders and among sites, with three possible categories: 0 < ω < 1, ω = 1, and ω  > 1, the latter being allowed only within toxic newts).

anns.postfix: and Taricha species), we fit the following models to our Nav alignments: 1) one-ratio models (allowing for a single ω ratio among all sites and all branches of the phylogeny), 2) branch models (allowing for separate ω ratios for the foreground [toxic newts] and background [other salamanders]), 3) branch-site neutral models (allowing ω to vary both between toxic newts and other salamanders and among sites, with two possible categories: 0 < ω < 1 and ω = 1), and 4) branch-site models (allowing ω to vary both between toxic newts and other salamanders and among sites, with three possible categories: 0 < ω < 1, ω = 1, and ω  > 1, the latter being allowed only within toxic newts).

anns.prefix: We performed all of the above analyses both including and excluding the two
anns.postfix: paralogs with a large number of gaps (Nav1.1 and Nav1.2).

anns.prefix: Therefore, we present results from the gene trees including
anns.postfix: here.

anns.prefix: We used a full codon alignment of all six Nav paralogs from seven of the eight salamanders included in the study (excluding
anns.postfix: due to missing data), but targeted our search to include only genes Nav1.1, Nav1.2, and Nav1.3 within each species under the assumption that gene conversion is more likely to occur between closely related sequences that reside on the same chromosome.
